Description: Fragment of terracotta group. Part of a group of a theatrical nature, with Omphale shown as an obese naked woman, standing on a low plinth. Her hair is parted in the centre and she wears a cap or veil over her head. She carries Herakles’ lion skin draped over her left arm, the head of the lion hanging by her side and its tail dangling below; Herakles’ club is held in the crook of her left arm. Omphale has broken away from another figure, presumably Herakles, standing on her right side, his arm round her shoulders and his hand resting on her upper left arm. The back is plain, with the top edge of a rectangular vent. Hollow; two-piece mould. Micaceous brown Nile silt with a reddish core; the front is covered with a buff-coloured surface.
Curator's comments: BM Terracotta IV Comparanda. None traced, but for the myth of Omphale and representations of her in art, see Boardman 1994: 45–53 and Zanker 1999: 120–31. Bibliog. Fischer 1994: no. 713.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3558)
